story: Jeffrey Epsteins pilot admits flying Prince Andrew on paedophiles private jetJeffrey Epsteins long time airman Lawrence Visoski said he was "familiar" with Prince Andrew when quizzed about flying the royal by defence lawyers for the British socialite Ghislaine MaxwellThe court heard claims that Prince Andrew flew aboard the private jet Image: Getty ImagesByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov A second pilot of Jeffrey Epsteinaposs has admitted flying Prince Andrew on board the paedophileaposs private jet, during evidence in Ghislaine Maxwellaposs sex trafficking case. The evidence was heard during the trial of the Duke of Yorkaposs pal in New York where she stands accused of grooming and abusing four minors. Epsteinaposs long time airman Lawrence Visoski said he was familiar with Prince Andrew when quizzed about flying the royal by defence lawyers for the British socialite. When asked by Maxwellaposs legal team: Are you familiar with Prince Andrew  Visoski replied Yes. Lawyer Christian Everdell then said: And he flew on Mr Epsteinaposs plane, right  Visoski responded, He did.  The airman became the second pilot to admit flying the Duke, , on Epsteinaposs jets. Captain Dave Rodgers has previously provided his flight logs in a civil case involving a victim of the late Wall Street financier that showed Andrew had taken several flights with the convicted sex offender. The evidence pours more pressure on the Duke to tell all he knows about Epstein as prosecutors and the FBI continue to probe the paedophileaposs sexual offending. As well as Andrew, Visoski recalled Bill Clinton, Donald Trump, Chris Tucker, astronaut John Glenn and actor Kevin Spacey all as passengers. While giving evidence yesterday the pilot testied Maxwell was “number two in Epstein’s world. Visoski, who is was called by prosecutors as their first witness, recalled how the British socialite would often contact him to schedule flights for the Wall Street financier.  Maxwell, who was once Epstein’s girlfriend, has been charged with recruiting and grooming four underage girls to give him erotic massages, describing them as a ruse for sex abuse. Ms Maxwell was number two. Mr Epstein was a big number one, Visoski told jurors. She was the one that pretty much handled most of the finance, my expenses, spending in the office.” When cross-examined by Mr Everdell, Visoski said that during his near -year employment he never witnessed any sex abuse or underage girls without their parents aboard. “I never saw any sexual activity, no,” the airmen, who was gted land by Epstein at his New Mexico Ranch, told Mr Everdell. Visoski said he did not notice any underage girls without their parents on the planes including Prince Andrew accuser Virginia Giuffre and a victim identied as “Jane” at the trial. At one point Mr Everdell asked: If Mr Epstein were engaging in sex acts with underage girls he probably would have told you not to leave the cockpit, correct   Prosecutors raised an objection which Judge Alison Nathan overruled. Visoski replied: Correct. The pilot said he flew Giuffre in the mid to late s, but believed her to be a “shorter woman with dirty blonde hair.” He added he believed a passenger named aposJaneapos - one of four women accusing Maxwell of sexual abuse - was a “mature woman with some piercing powder blue eyes.” Prosecutors entered a birth certicate for Jane, whose identity is protected, into evidence under seal. Maxwell, , has pleaded not guilty to eight counts of sex trafficking and other crimes, including two perjury charges that will be tried at a later date. She faces up to  years in prisonconvicted on all counts. Lawyers for Maxwell have said the British socialite was being scapegoated for crimes Epstein committed. The financier died in jail in August  while awaiting trial on sex-abuse charges. Earlier yesterday, Judge Nathan said she had excused one juror from the case because his spouse had surprised him with a planned trip around the Christmas holiday.  As a result,  jurors and five alternates, instead of six, will continue hearing testimony in the expected six-week trial, which began on Monday. Visoskiaposs testimony provided jurors with a sense of the lestyle she lived between  and , the period in which prosecutors say the Brit - the daughter of disgraced tycoon Robert Maxwell - lured four underage girls for Epstein to abuse. The pilot said he frequently shuttled Epstein and guests between the billionaireaposs properties in New York, Florida, New Mexico, Paris and Caribbean islands. In her opening statement on Monday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Lara Pomerantz said prosecutors would present flight logs that included the names of Maxwell and some of the alleged victims. Maxwellaposs defence attorney, Bobbi Sternheim, responded saying there was nothing inherently wrong with having private jets. news uk-news omicron-covid-cancel-christmas-what-"Omicron: Health minister says Christmas will hopefully not be ruinedByMatt RoperFeatures writerDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments We were all looking forward to a more normal Christmas this year and then along came Omicron.Brits are already being urged not not socialise when we don’t particularly need to” by experts in a bid to deal with the spread of the new Covid iant.UKHSA head Dr Jenny Harries, told BBC Radio ’s Today programme: “Our behaviours in winter and particularly around Christmas we tend to socialise more so I think all of those will need to be taken into account.”Asked whether people should be told to work from home in England, as is happening in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, she said: “We’ve seen that not everybody has gone back to work and I’d like to think of it more in a general way, which iswe all decrease our social contacts a little bit, actually that helps to keep the iant at bay. “So I think being careful, not socialising when we don’t particularly need to and particularly going and getting those booster jabs.”  So far nine people have been identied with Omicron in Scotland, along with five in England. Dr Harries said there could be a further  “highly likely” cases.But how concerned should we be about the new coronavirus iant and could it really derail our festive plans Prof Azeem Majeed, professor of primary care and public health at Imperial College London, has the answers…How worried should we be about the Omicron iant When any new iant of the virus that causes Covid- is identied, we don’t at first know how infectious it will be, whether it will cause a more serious illness than other iants and how well vaccines will work against it. We therefore need to be cautious and take measures to control the spread of Omicron until this information becomes available. We shouldn’t, however, become unduly anxious. I’ve heard that the iant causes more mild symptoms. Is that true andso why are we worried Some early reports from South Africa suggest that Omicron may cause a milder illness than other iants. However, we will need data from many more people infected with the Omicron iant – particularly older and clinically vulnerable people – before we can reach reliable conclusions about the severity of the illness it causes.Why are they giving more booster jabsthe new iant can evade existing vaccines Two doses of current vaccines provide good protection – and three doses provides even better protection – against the other strains of coronavirus. At present, we have no evidence the Omicron iant can evade existing vaccines. We need to continue with the booster programme as this has been very effective in keeping down the number of infections that can result in hospital admission or death. Does the new iant transmit any dferently We don’t yet have good data on whether Omicron can infect people more easily than other iants. It will gradually emerge in the coming weeks.Does it mean existing Covid treatments like the new antiviral treatments won’t work either  It is possible that some of the newer antiviral treatments won’t work aswell against Omicron as against other iants. However, this will need to be confirmed in research studies.It’s very likely, however, that antiviral treatments will still reduce the severity of illness caused by Omicron.What don’t we know about Omicron and when will we know We currently lack important information about Omicron – such as how infectious it is, whether it causes a more severe illness than other iants, how well vaccines protect against it and whether antiviral drugs will be helpful in reducing the severity of illness it causes. Research is already underway to answer all of these questions. How likely is it to affect Christmas and how We currently have a high Covid- infection rate in the UK. Fortunately, vaccines are keeping down the number of people with a more severe illness, which in turn is keeping the number of hospital admissions and deaths low. If we can get a high uptake of boosters, we should be able to have a more normal Christmas. But everyone should continue with infection control measures and not rely just on vaccination. People who are not vaccinated at allshould also come forward.Will mask wearing really stop it Masks can reduce the spread of infection – particularlya higher specication FFP mask is worn. But they work best when combined with other infection control measures such as vaccination and home-working.Will bringing forward boosters mean they’re not as efficient Bringing forward the booster to three months instead of six after people’s second vaccination won’t reduce its effectiveness in preventing serious illness. The booster dose substantially increases people’s immunity and this can help stop the Omicron iant evading our current vaccines. If the time between jabs is now three months, does that mean I’ll soon need a fourthI had my booster weeks ago The three month gap is for people who have not yet had a booster. If you have already had your booster, you won’t get a fourth dose . Those who have not yet had a booster no longer have to wait six months from their second dose and can have this earlier.What will happen in schools Many schools in England have had large Covid- outbreaks since the new school year started. It’s important that - year old children are vaccinated and also get a second vaccination once the Government has approved this. People working in schools also need to be fully vaccinated with three doses . Any child who is unwell with possible Covid- symptoms should get a PCR test and isolate until the result is back. Improving ventilation and air quality in schools is also essential to reduce the risk of infection. Could there be more travel bans If the Omicron iant spreads further, then more countries may be placed on the Red List. This can happen at very short notice, leaving travellers with the option of either cutting short their trip or facing an expensive stay in a quarantine hotel. Everyone should consider thisthey are planning an overseas trip.Where will I need to wear a face mask Face coverings will be mandatory by law in England’s shops, public transport, hairdressers, banks and post offices from am on Tuesday. Those who do not comply can be fined £ for a first offence , doubling on each repeat offence up to £,. Police will be expected to enforce rules.The Government has not published a full list but masks will not be mandatory in pubs and restaurants or cinemasand theatres like they were before. What are the new foreign travel rules From am on Tuesday, all arrivals in the UK from anywhere in the world must take a paid-for PCR test within  hours of their arrival and isolate until the result comes back negative. Previously, vaccinated travellers only had to take a lateral flow Day  test and did not have to isolate. The new rules apply even to the double-jabbed. Arrivals who land without having booked a Day  test in advance can be fined £, on the spot. Arrival from Red List countries must go into hotel quarantine costing £, a head for  nights. Those who breach isolation can be fined up to £,. When will I have to self-isolate All close contacts of suspected Omicron cases will have to isolate for  days, regardless of their jab status. People who test positive for Covid must still self-isolate for  days and unvaccinated or partially vaccinated close contacts of a Covid case must do the same, regardless of which iant they have.What are the rules in schools The Government is “strongly advising” school pupils above Year , staff and visitors to wear masks in communal areas. Local public health teams can send groups of pupils home as a last-ditch measure to stop the spread.Can Christmas parties and gatherings go ahead Yes, there is no legal restriction on Christmas parties. People do not need to wear masks or show a vaccine passport in hospitality venues.Health Minister Edward Argar said people in England can “use their judgment” about whetherto attend festive bashes this year.Will the rules be tightened further  It is possible. Boris Johnson has not yet enacted all of England’s Plan B measures, leaving vaccine passports for nightclubs and stadiums in reserve.And people have not been advised to work from home where possible, despite advice of that kind in Scotland. The PM is not planning to adopt Scotland and Wales’ plea for eight days’ isolation for travellers who enter the country, but has not ruled it out.When will they expire They will expire on December  with a review ahead of that meaning they could be strengthened for Christmas. story: Picture of electric car parked on pavement sparks fierce charging point debatePeople have been accused of electric vehicle shaming but many agreed the person was selfish for parking up on the pavement to charge the BMW with the cable stretching over the front gardenThe BMW was parked on the pavement in Cardf while the vehicle was being charged-up Image: TwitterByReem AhmedSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Dec | comments An image of an electric car being charged-up on a pavement has caused a big stir online. The picture was uploaded to facebook after a resident in Cardf, Wales, spotted the electric BMW while on a walk, reports WalesOnline.A cable can be seen stretching from the home over the front garden of the property, connecting to the charging point of the car. It has sparked a big debate online about the practicality of electric vehicles - and the loss of pedestrianised spaces. The dad who uploaded the photo said a big re-think is needed. He captioned the post: Genuinely staggered to come across this on a walk with the baby. Since the s we’ve given so much space over to petrol cars.  We can’t allow the small pockets left for people to be given over to electric cars. But things didnapost end there, with more people chipping in with their views on the subject. One responded: This just wonapost do. Itaposs obstructing the footway with a vehicle – its mode of propulsion does not change that. That was echoed by another user, who said: You donapost get to block the pavement with your private property, go and charge it somewhere . Other agreed saying the car owner was being selfish. If you want to connect to the house give up your garden donapost ask me to give up the footpath, said a third before adding: I would be tempted to walk over that.  But not everyone saw eye-to-eye on the debate. One person posted: How about you finding an issue where there isn’t one  Plenty of room to get past, they’re just trying to create the safest situation they can. Would you prefer a long cable draped across to the road  Because that’s their other choice here. Find something real to get annoyed about. Another fumed: EV [electric vehicle] shaming - I get itaposs annoying, but that is a pretty wide pavement. story: Queen once served builder cup of tea after embarrassing encounter in palaceThe Buckingham Palace workman was visiting to dismantle a desk when an unexpected person offered him a brewThe oblivious builder responded to the Queen without realising who she was Image: Getty ImagesByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsAn oblivious builder had an unfortunate encounter with the Queen when he told her he didnapost want any of that nonsense I had last time when she offered him a cup of tea. The Buckingham Palace workman was visiting to dismantle a desk when an unexpected person offered him a brew. Speaking on Channel  documentary Secrets of the Royal Palaces, Royal Upholsterer Kevin Andrews, who worked for the late Queen Mother, explained what happened. He said: “A builder was dismantling a desk so he could not see who was making the offer when the ladyaposs voice asked himhe would like a cup of tea.”  Without realising it was the Queen herself who answered, he is said to have replied: “Yeah. In a mug. Two sugars. Builderaposs tea. “I donapost want any of that nonsense I had the last time I was here, all that fine china and all that saucer stuff.” Without saying anything, the Queen dropped off his cup of tea on the table, and by the time he went to pick it up the builder could only look on as he saw her walking away. The Queen is likely to have found the encounter funny, as she is known for her humour and good nature when she meets oblivious people. title: tesco confirms new covid rules
story: Tesco confirms new Covid rules now in place in supermarkets as iant spreadsTesco CEO Jason Tarry sent an email to customers this afternoon with details about the measures, including mask-wearing and a traffic light system, that will be enforced in stores from todayTesco has rolled out a series of Covid measures in its stores, including mask wearingByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov  Tesco has confirmed its new Covid rules amid fears of the new Omicron strain. The supermarketaposs CEO Jason Tarry sent an email to customers this afternoon with details of five changes across stores to prevent the spread of the virus.His announcement contradicts an earlier report from the BBC which said several UK supermarkets, including Tesco, would not enforce the Governmentaposs mask-wearing law.In the email, Mr Tarry said it will be a legal requirement for customers to wear a face covering in our stores . Tesco, the UKaposs largest supermarket chain, will also operate a traffic light system in most large stores and the busiest Express stores.  The system will help staff to monitor the flow of customers and prevent overcrowding. Hand sanitisers will be placed at store entrances for people to clean their hands and wipe down baskets and trolleys. Protective screens have been installed around each checkout - which are now all open to reduce queuing times. Staff have designated separate exits and entrances to make entering and leaving the store as easy as possible.  Mr Tarry also asked customers to remember drivers and in-store staff are still working very hard in dficult circumstances to feed the nation. So we’d just ask everyone to please be kind, patient and respectful as we try to keep everyone safe, he said. It comes after the BBC reported several stores would not enforce mask wearing. Iceland said customers would not be asked to don masks to stop them facing abuse. The earlier report suggested Tesco would only put signs up to advise customers to wear masks. Budget stores Aldi and Lidl will also avoid challenging customers, the BBC reports.News of the soft approach follows an announcement from industry body The British Retail Consortium, who said police should enforce the rule rather than retailers.  Greeters and security guards will remind people to cover up at Sainsburyaposs, according to the broadcaster. Morrisons will dish out masks to customers who have forgotten them and check people as they enter. Asda will also provide face coveringsneeded. And Iceland chief Richard Walker said it was unfair to put staff at risk of abuse from people who donapost want to put a mask on. He said: They are already working under signicant pressure, especially as we hit the busiest trading month of the year. I wonapost be putting my staff at any risk of confrontation or abuse, he said. story: Whopping dog weighing the same as a baby elephant named slimmer of the yearIn November  Trojan was taken to the RSPCA tipping the scales at a hefty kg, prompting him to be put on a radical weight loss regime that has borne fruit after  monthsTrojan the dog used to be quite chunky Image: BPM MEDIAByPaul McAuley:,  Nov | commentsA dog who shed half his body weight in  months has been branded ‘slimmer of the year’. In November  Trojan was taken to the RSPCA tipping the scales at a hefty kg.That is a full kg heavier than an average female elephant at birth, Dorset Live reported.Just a year on, the lovable canine now comes in at a much healthier .kg and is said to be feeling much better for it. Kennel supervisor Nicola Anthony, who has been helping care for the Alaskan malamute in Dorset, explained: Poor Trojan was in a terrible way when he arrived here a year ago. He was dirty, matted and unbelievably obese. Do you have a hefty pet  Email webnews@mirror “It’s taken a year, a very special diet and an exercise regime to help him lose the weight slowly and safely and he’s now almost half of his original weight. Thankfully, he hasn’t lost his big character.” However, the senior pooch is now looking for a home that can keep his previous health and age in mind when taking him on. Trojan suffers from arthritis and thyroid problems so will need ongoing treatment in his new home. These conditions wonapost be covered by any insurance, so any potential owners will need to be prepared to cover costs. Nicola added: “Although he’s in his twilight years, don’t let that fool you he has no intention of ‘retiring’ any time soon. He is still strong and likes to go for short walks, plod around the garden and have a good snf. He gets on really well with other dogs but doesn’t like being jumped all over so he’s best around calm, respectful doggy friends. Trojan is looking for a home where he’ll have good company, regular grooming and be the only dog.  Nicola said: “While the festive season may be a time to join together with family and friends, many animals, like Trojan, will be waiting patiently to find their new family in an RSPCA rescue centre. It will cost us £, to run an animal centre for one day this winter so we’re asking animal lovers to join the aposRescue this Christmasapos to make sure animals get the care they need this winter.” RSPCA chief veterinary officer Caroline Allen said: “Pet obesity is a serious welfare issue and recent studies have suggested that around half of all pet dogs are overweight. We are, quite literally, killing our pets with kindness. Obesity can affect all types of pets and the main causes are from eating too much or not exercising enough. As a rough guide , you should be able to see and feel the outline of their ribs without excess fat covering them. You should also be able to see and feel their waist and it should clearly ‘pinch in’ when you look down at them from above. Overweight pets can suffer from serious health problems such as heart disease and diabetes and carrying more body weight than needed can also increase the chances of pets suffering from conditions such as arthritis and can even shorten their le expectancy. The RSPCA have stressed the importance of sticking to healthy diets for dogs and not to overfeed or overtreat them, especially with Christmas approaching. Jan Richardson, who lives in the area, said she saw it being put up while gales were blowing due to Storm Arwen. She said: I watched the tree being taken off the lorry the other night and they had a dreadful time with the wind.  The installation of the festive decorations has not been smooth sailing as the townaposs first tree was damaged in transit.Carol Whyte commented on Facebook : They had only one job to do.Gemma Shepherd added that it looked aposlike her treeapos. After locals pointed out the problems with the the festive fir it has now been aposstraightenedapos. Graham Burgess, leader of Gosport Borough Council, said: I believe the tree was straightened. title: i refuse elf shelf house
story: I refuse to do Elf on the Shelf in my house - its creepy and I cant be botheredWhy are parents tearing their hair out with yet more pre-Christmas admin  Just chuck your Elf on the Shelf in the bin and save yourself the hassle, writes mum of two Kirsty KetleyTheres absolutely no way youll ever find this little creep in my house Image: InstagramopinionByKirsty Ketley:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsChristmas traditions have evolved somewhat since my childhood of the s, and being a parent myself now, I love creating new ones with my children.I am all up for matching PJs and Christmas bedding, Michael Bublé on repeat and hot chocolate bombs, but the one new tradition that doesn’t happen in our house is Elf on the Shelf. To say I hate it is perhaps a bit harsh, but I do have a very strong dislike to it and here’s why. Firstly, I really cannot be bothered. The time and effort that goes into having an Elf come to stay is time and effort that I really don’t have at this time of year. Parent admin is never-ending as it is, and there is so much more during December – I barely keep up with what my kids need throughout the month.I definitely don’t need to add a Twinkletoeson top.  I once thought about jumping on the elf bandwagon, until my daughter was at a friendaposs house and one freaked her out. You see, many young children have vivid imaginations and I have spent many hours reassuring both my children that their teddy hasn’t moved all by itself. or that ghosts and monsters are not real. I am not then going to welcome an Elf into the house – who quite frankly is creepy as… - and undo all my hard work. Then there is the worry that the Elf is going to wake me in the dead of night and remind me that I haven’t moved it, as so many parents report. Sleep is precious, the kids now sleep through - Iaposm not allowing an Elf to ruin it!  It isn’t just a case of moving little Elfie about the house though - the pressure is on parents now to get creative. Kids want to be surprised by Twinkletoes’ shenanigans. Undecorating the tree, ‘pooping’ in the Cheerios, or using toilet paper as a parachute to swing from the chandelier, after leaving flour footprints and chaos in its wake. It’s a naughty elf and, isn’t that just a little hypocritical  I mean, sending an elf to watch the kids and report back to Santa, while being less than well behaved itself  For me, the whole concept is unnecessary. As a kid, the threat was just that Santa was watching. How he was watching never occurred to me, but I always knew that he would be there.You see, telling your kids that Santa won’t come is an empty threat, which I think most parents - including myself - have said several times throughout December. But which parent is actually going to follow that one through and leave their kid with no presents on Christmas Day I am very up for people doing Christmas their own way, and soyou love Elf on the Shelf, that’s fine - but you sure as hell wonapost find one in my house.Do you do Elf on the Shelf for your kids  Have your say in the comments belowRead MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Father ChristmasMichael BubleElf on the ShelfChristmas decorations" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: I spent a fortune turning house into my dream home - now I’m being kicked outA mum on TikTok has been left fuming after her landlord told her she has to move out of her rental home by January – after shed spent a lot of money transforming the propertyChannay isnt happy about the situation Image: @cleaningmum TikTokByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Dec | comments Living in a rented home is becoming more and more popular as people continue to struggle to get on the property ladder.And while those in rentals don’t own the house they live in, many of them will still add their own personal touches to make their stay more enjoyable.But one mum on TikTok has been left outraged after she spent a pretty penny completely redecorating her rental to make it her dream home – only to be told by her landlord that he’s kicking her out so he can sell the property on. Channay, who posts under the username @cleaningmum, said she had been handed a notice by her landlord telling her she has to be out of the property by January, even though she’s the one who did all the work on the house. She wrote in one video: “When you’ve just spent ££££ on the house you live in for the landlord to give you a notice to leave by January. And in update videos, she claimed that her landlord never kept up with any maintenance jobs on the house, so she was always left to do it herself. She added: “When your landlord doesn’t keep up with the maintenance so you do it yourself and then he puts it up for sale. news world-news meet-lonely-princess-set-become-"Emperor Akihito thanks Japanese in farewell and prays for peaceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsShe’s the little-known princess who appeared to have a lonely childhood blighted by school bullying and health problems.But today Princess Aiko of Japan, daughter of Emperor Nahurito, celebrates her th birthday - and it will mark her entrance into official public le, where she will carry out royal duties.On Sunday, she will enter the world stage in an official ceremony to mark her coming-of-age, where she will be expected to wear formal dress and even a tiara. And she’s already pledged her service to her country. In a statement released by the Imperial Household Agency to mark her birthday, she said: “I would like to refine myself and move forward step by step so that I can grow into an adult who can be of service to others.”  But who exactly is Princess Aiko and what will her future hold  We take a look… Only child Princess Aiko, also known as Princess Toshi, is the only child of Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako.She was born at Tokyoaposs Imperial Palace in  and her parents broke with tradition by choosing her name rather than leaving it to her grandfather, former Emperor Akihito.Aiko is her personal name, while her imperial title Toshi means a person who respects others. School struggles Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.When she was just eight years old, Aiko refused to go to school because she said she was the victim of bullying.She was eventually persuaded toto the classroom but onlyher mother could go too. It was some time before she felt confident to go to school on her own. Aiko’s parents tried to make her school days more bearable by regularly inviting her classmates to the palace. An investigation revealed that she had suffered “violent things” from boys in another class. The school, however, explained away the incident, claiming that two boys accidentally collided with her, “which scared her”. Health problems  In October , there were more worries about the princess when she missed nearly two months from school due to an unspecied illness. Palace officials confirmed the teenager had been complaining of stomach problems and dizziness, which they attributed to studying for exams as well as practising for an athletics event. She later attended Gakushuin Girls’ Senior High School, where the princess was able to spend three months studying at Eton in Britain, staying in a boarding house. Aiko then started accompanying her parents on royal duties after her father ascended to the Chrysanthemum Throne in . She is currently enrolled at Gakushuin University, where she has been attending online classes due to the Covid pandemic.According to the Japan Times, she studies Japanese literature, English and Spanish as well as Japanese history and traditional art.In September, she moved from the Akasaka Imperial Residence to the Imperial Palace with her parents taking her dog Yuri and cats Mii and Seven with her. Entering royal le  Now she has turned , Aiko will be formally welcomed into public le in a ceremony set to take place on Sunday. While dressed in formal attire, she will visit sanctuaries where the Imperial Familyaposs ancestors are buried and offer prayers to the gods, as well as be greeted by her parents and grandparents. Part of her formal attire will be a tiara, however itaposs been reported that the one she will wear for the ceremony will be a second-hand one - and not made especially for her. The tiara she will wear was first made for her aunt Princess Sayako but it is thought that the piece is being adjusted so it fits her perfectly on her big day. Itaposs said that there was some surprise in Japan, when it was announced that no new tiara was being made for the occasion. Future le  Once her official coming-of-age ceremony is out of the way, it is believed Aikoaposs first public appearance will be on New Yearaposs Day, when members of Japanaposs Imperial Family meet with well-wishers at Tokyoaposs Imperial Palace. She will also continue her university studies and in March will appear at a traditional coming-of-age news conference. However, depending on how Aikoaposs adult le pans out, her time in Japanaposs Imperial Family could be short.Thataposs becausea female member of the Imperial Family marries a commoner, she will lose her royal status and even her title.Earlier this year, her cousin Princess Mako was forced to relinquish her title when she married her commoner long-term love Kei Komuro.Before Makoaposs wedding, there were emotional scenes when she was forced to say goodbye to her parents and younger sister Kako at the entrance to their home.Though all wore masks in line with Japanaposs coronavirus protocol, her mother could be seen blinking rapidly, asto fight off tears.Mako bowed formally to her parents but her sister grabbed her shoulders and the two shared a long embrace. Chrysanthemum Throne  Of course, Aiko may choose not to marry - but despite being the only child of the Emperor, she will not ascend to the throne because women are not allowed to rule over Japan. In Japan there are just three heirs to the throne, Emperor Naruhito’s younger brother Crown Prince Akishino, , his son Prince Hisahito, , and the emperor’s uncle Prince Hitachi, . Experts have warned the royal line could completely vanishthe Imperial House Law is not revised. In , an expert  called for a revision to the law to allow the imperial couple’s first born, regardless of gender, to ascend the throne. But this was halted with the birth of Prince Hisahito in  - the was the first male member of the Imperial Family born in nearly  years. There are also fears that banning women from marrying outside the nobility, effectively forcing them to leave the Royal Familythey chose to wed, means the busy schedule of official duties is falling onto fewer and fewer people. Relaxing the rules is popular in Japan, with  per cent of people said to be supportive of allowing women to become emperors, not least because it would keep the monarchy relevant in an ever-changing world. But Japan’s former prime minister Shinzo Abe was reportedly against allowing women to rule, believing that because the throne has consistently been passed down through the male line, it should continue the same way. confident that he has found the site of the crashed plane about , miles to the west of Australia in the Indian Ocean. Richard Godfrey says he has been using new tracking technology that he claims has allowed him to locate the Boeing - , believing it is ,ft below the surface. The technology works using “tripwires” around the globe and when the plane hits one the signal changes. The Malaysia Airlines plane disappeared on a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on March , , with  people on board. The aviation engineer now claims that he has been able to track the plane’s final movements using a new system called weak signal propagation. Mr Godfrey told Australiaaposs  News it was like having a “bunch of tripwires that work in every direction over the horizon to the other side of the globe.”He has reportedly combined this new technology with data from the satellite communications system onboard the plane to track its path. “Together the two systems can be used to detect, identy and localise MH during its flight path into the Southern Indian Ocean,” he reportedly said. In his report he states that the plane crashed at .am. He is now “very confident” that he has found the plane. “We have quite a lot of data from the satellite, we have oceanography, drt analysis, we have the performance data from Boeing, and now this new technology, he said. “All four align with one particular point in the Indian Ocean.”  He also has a theory for the crash and believes that it was deliberately carried out by the pilot Zaharie Ahmad Shah as a terrorism act and the captain wanted the plane to “disappear in one of the remotest places in the world.” There is optimism that it could be the location of the plane as it is not far from where other searches have taken place. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: i look back with pride and a smile swimmer hannah miley retires
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: battling star hold title favourites

title: galas-chance-put-town-football-map
story: ARGUABLY Gala Fairydean Roversrsquo biggest game of the season takes place on Saturday when League Two Annan Athletic visit Netherdale in the third round of the Scottish Cup.The winners will go into Monday nightrsquos draw along with the giants of Scottish football ndash and potentially a huge pay day could be the reward.Manager Neil Hastings is not underestimating the challenge ahead and is urging fans to create a good atmosphere and cheer the team onto victory.He told the Border : ldquoSaturday will be a huge challenge against a team who perform at a higher level."Itrsquos the biggest competition we play in, and we have the chance to reach the fourth round. title: mccallum-hoping-world-title-eliminator-vegas
story: Galashiels boxer John McCallumrsquos IBF Intercontinental Cruiserweight title fight against Kazakhstan fighter Issa Akberbayev at York Hall was postponed at the last minute.The fight had been scheduled for Friday  November but Akberbayev withdrew citing illness two days before.A previous fight between the pair was called off by Akberbayev due to Covid.A frantic search to find another opponent for the McCallum failed and he is now in talks about a world title eliminator in Las Vegas next month.A disappointed McCallum told the Border : ldquoThat fight was for meant to be for my dad Steven Robinson who is seriously ill with cancer in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital and that has been taken away.ldquoI had a massive support and many of them were spending the weekend in London.ldquoIrsquom really annoyed and it has even made me think of chucking it. The whole thing has been a massive disappointment. It wasnrsquot about belts or money it was for my dad and as soon as I found out I drove to Edinburgh to be with him.ldquoI donrsquot think Irsquoll be fighting Akberbayev again after the two call offs. This was an oral virus which meant he was unable to fly.ldquoIrsquove been asked to fight Andrew Tabiti who is in the Mayweather camp for a world title eliminator which would take place in Las Vegas on -December at the Mandalay Bay and Irsquom up for that. The Intercontinental belt is still vacant butthis comes off Irsquoll bypass that.ldquoI peaked for the Akberbayev so Irsquoll have a few days rest then get back in training at my local gym before heading to Vegas about five days before the fight. Irsquom in good shape so that should be OK.

title: date-announced-next-years-maroond-gala-festival
story: BUILDING on its success in , the Maroonrsquod@Gala sports and music festival willto Netherdale next year.The event will take place at the home of Gala Rugby, on Saturday, August , .Praised for its innovation and inclusivity, the inaugural edition of Maroonrsquod@Gala provided competition opportunities for primary school age rugby players under s under s under s senior and ladies sections and players with physical and learning disabilities.It also played host to football and running events.In addition to the showpiece sporting event ndash which culminated with the final of the famous Gala Sevens - there were live bands, street food, themed drinks areas and fun zones.Despite challenging weather conditions and the requirement to work in accordance with government coronavirus guidance, the free  event was attended by around ,-, people.It received positive feedback with participants, vendors and spectators stating their intention tofor future editions.Ian Dalgleish, the president of Gala RFC, said: ldquoThe Maroonrsquod@Gala concept has been very well received and the success of our inaugural event this summer, coupled with positive feedback and the continued support of our partners, has given us confidence to bring it back in .ldquoTogether, wersquore committed to creating a community event that local people want to be part of and to celebrate the proud sporting history of Gala Rugby, as well as to inspire our future stars."We also want to build on what we achieved this year and to extend the feel-good factor beyond the Netherdale site, maximising the positive economic impact in Galashiels town centre.Maroonrsquod@Gala was initially scheduled to take place in April  but was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Further details will be announced in due course.

title: peebles-man-runs-marathon-memory-late-father
story: PEEBLES man Steve Murray along with three of his friends has raised pound,. for the Alec Lucas Memorial Trust, by running a marathon around the town.The four men decided to undertake the challenge on October , despite the heavy rain, as that day marked the th anniversary of the unexpected and tragic death of Steversquos father, Steve lsquoScousersquo Murray at the age of .Steve told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoMy dad was my hero, and I canrsquot put into words how dficult his passing has been for me. I still think about him every day and get upset thinking about the things hersquos missed out on being a part of. Coming up to this particular anniversary, I knew I wanted to do something to commemorate his le and to make him proud.The Murrayrsquos moved to the Borders  years ago and were neighbours of the Lucas family so the decision to make the Alec Lucas Memorial Trust their chosen charity was an easy one.The Trust was started by in memory of the -year-old Royal Marine Commando who was killed in action in Kajaki, Afghanistan on November ,  and has raised thousands of pounds for charity.Steve continued: ldquoThe Lucas family were our neighbours in Whitehaugh#Park, I have#known them since moving to Peebles from Liverpool in .##Alec was our first babysitter, and wersquod have him playing football in the garden for hours. Dad#was very fond#of Alec, having gotten to know him better through#drinking in the#Crown, and I know he would be fully behind#this choice of charity.#ldquoWhen I first started drinking in the pubs, Alec always made a point of coming over for a chat, checking I was alright, and buying me a bevy. He didnrsquot have to do that, but it was reassuring to know you had an ally in the pub when you didnrsquot know many people. Raising money for his charity is an honour.ldquoInitially we hoped to raise pound, and didnrsquot expect to raise over pound,.Alecs father Adrian added: "On behalf of the Fund Id like to offer huge congratulations to Steve, Richard, Finlay and Duncan for a fantastic effort. The money raised will go to the Royal Marines charities to support serving and retired Royal Marines, of which Alec was a proud member.".removeThe other runners were Richard Harragan, Finlay Moffat and Duncan McPherson.Anyone wishing to donate can do so at https:uk.virginmoneygiving StephenMurray before November .

title: scotland-women-head-dubai-february-cup-qualifiers
story: THE WOMENS edition of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament will take place on  and  February  at The Sevens Stadium in Dubai.Scotland will compete alongside Samoa, Colombia and the winner of the Hong Kong v Kazakhstan playoff for the last remaining place at Rugby World Cup  in New Zealand, now due to take place between  Octoberndash November, .The Final Qualication Tournament will operate in a semi-final, final format over two match days.This is the first time the womenrsquos edition of Rugby World Cup has featured a Final Qualication Tournament offering teams a second pathway to qualy for RWC  with the winner booking their place in Pool A alongside hosts New Zealand, Australia and Wales next year.Eleven teams have already booked their place at Rugby World Cup , including New Zealand, England, France, Canada, USA, Australia and Wales, who qualied through their final ranking at Ireland , and South Africa, Fiji, Italy and Japan who qualied through their regions.Rugby World Cup  Tournament Director, Alison Hughes, said: ldquoWe are pleased to be able to share the details of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament. A first for a womenrsquos edition of a Rugby World Cup the tournament offers teams a second opportunity to qualy for the pinnacle event and we anticipate a thrilling contest between competing teams in Dubai in February.Tom Burwell, The Sevens Stadium General Manager, said, ldquoWe are hugely excited to host world-class womenrsquos XVs rugby at The Sevens Stadium. It will be the first time such a competition has taken place in the UAE. With the Emirates Dubai s ing over the next two weekends, itrsquos an exciting time for rugby in the region. We are honoured to be working with World Rugby once more in delivering international rugby. With the winner going onto New Zealand and RWC , we are excited to be part of a nationrsquos journey to the very top of the womenrsquos game..removeThe RWC  Final Qualication Tournament will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.Rugby World Cup  will be the showpiece event in womenrsquos rugby union s, with the first tickets for Rugby World Cup  selling out in minutes. Tournament organisers are calling on fans to secure their tickets early to avoid disappointment.

title: greystone-knowe-14-turbine-borders-wind-farm-plans-filed
story: PLANS for a -turbine wind farm in the Borders have been filed with the council.The Greystone Knowe development ndash around . km west of Fountainhall ndash is a joint venture between ESB and Coriolis Energy, according to papers submitted as part of the application.Scotlandrsquos current climate change ambitions has been given as a reason for the proposed turbines, which would have a maximum tip height of m.Documents submitted to the council state: ldquoThe UK and Scotlandrsquos current climate change ambitions are amongst the highest in Europe. The Scottish government declared a climate emergency in May  and has recently passed the Climate Change Bill which has passed into law the requirement for a  per cent reduction in CO emissions by  and an interim target of  per cent reduction in emissions by .ldquoLooking beyond to , the Scottish Energy Strategy target for  per cent of total energy demandfrom renewable sources implies a further substantial increase in delivery required.ldquoAs such, the Scottish Government looks to encourage all renewable and low carbon solutions for meeting the energy target.On the location, the report adds: ldquoThe Greystone Knowe project area has not formed a part of any previously proposed onshore wind development and has the capacity to make a valuable contribution to national policy aims.ldquoIn addition, experience in the local community now indicates that the shared benefits of wind energy development can make a valuable contribution towards local community needs through community benefit funds as well as investment and employment during construction.If approved, the turbines would be the biggest of the operational wind farms within km of the site.According to the papers, there are three developments within that radius.Carcant, near Heriot, has three turbines with a maximum height of m, while Oxtonrsquos Toddleburn has  turbines with the tallest at m. title: garvald-west-linton-new-building-only-way-meet-clients-needs
story: A BORDERS care provider says a new accommodation block is the ldquoonly way it can meet the needs of its clients.Plans for the ldquopurpose-built structure on the Garvald House estate, West Linton, have been submitted to Scottish Borders Council.Garvald West Linton provides residential accommodation for adults with learning dficulties across a mix of modern and listed buildings.And the charity is now proposing to develop a new detached residential building for six residents.A report attached to the application states that: ldquoThe needs of the client group have changed over recent years. We now have clients with more complex needs.ldquoWhat is meant by complex needs is that alongside a cognitive impairment there are also underlying medical conditions.ldquoThe age profile of our client is also increasing with over half of the client group now in their s.It adds: ldquoWe need to improve our accommodation to manage this ever-increasing level of need. Much of the accommodation is over two levels and, for those with mobility issues, we need to have level access accommodation.ldquoWe also need to provide improved levels of privacy leading to the creation of en-suite facilities for each client.ldquoIt has come into sharp focus that some of the current buildings do not meet modern standards of infection control. Examples would be the lack of staff changing facilities and the number of clients sharing toilet facilities.ldquoWe anticipate that this will be a regulatory requirement in the near future.ldquoThe increased level of need has seen the requirement for increased attendance space and storage of mobility equipment.Garvald West Linton currently provides care to  people with learning disabilities.The proposed site is located away from Garvald House so as to not adversely affect the ldquosetting, character and appearance of the B-listed building.The ground levels will need to be adjusted to accommodate the development, according to the report, giving an opportunity to ldquotuck the new building into the landscape..removeIf approved, each resident will have their own flat with an en-suite bedroom, living room and kitchen.A shared living dining room, accessible bathroom, multi-use space, kitchen, laundry, storage space and plant room will also be provided.A managerrsquos office and staff accommodation are included in the plans.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today---omicron-variant-new-rules-considered
story: Nicola Sturgeon held an emergency Covid briefing today as the first cases of the Omicron iant were identied in Scotland.The first minister was joined by Scotlands chief medical officer Dr Gregor Smith to detail what they currently know about the situation in Scotland.The new Omicron iant, which was first discovered in South Africa, has led to countries around the world tightening restrictions amid concerns it could be more transmissible than the Delta iant.UK prime minister Boris Johnson announced tighter measures on mask wearing and travel over the weekend for England, reintroducing mandatory face coveringsin shops and on public transport.Meanwhile, in Scotland, face coverings have been compulsory in these settings throughout the majority of the pandemic as highlighted yesterday by the first minister on the Andrew Marr Show.As the Omicron iant continues to dominate headlines, heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today....  Omicron cases detected so far in ScotlandSome of the  cases currently detected have no link to travel to or from South Africa, which suggests there could be some level to community transmission.. "Signicantly" increase compliance with current rulesThe Scottish government is asking people to signicantly increase compliance with the current rules in place: wearing face coverings, taking regular lateral flow tests, getting vaccinated and maintaining high levels of hygiene.. No evidence currently to suggest disease caused by Omicron is more severeAccording to the WHO, there is currently no evidence to suggest that illness caused by the Omicron iant is more severe.However, the first minister said this remained under review. Situation in Scotland stableAlthough the first minister couldnt provide a detailed updated on the figures in Scotland, which will be published later today, she confirmed that the current situation in Scotland was stable..remove. Travel restrictions could be tightenedNicola Sturgeon has written a joint letter with Welsh leader Mark Drakeford to the UK government urging a four nations policy to introduce an -day self-isolation period for people arriving from overseas.The first minister said:"We are proposing a tougher four-nations approach to travel restrictions at this stage that would see people arriving in the UK from overseas asked to self-isolate for eight days. In our proposal, they would take a PCR test on day eight of their arrival, as well as on day ."Currently  countries are on the red list andanyone arriving in Scotland from anywhere outside the common travel area, will be asked to take a PCR Covid test on the second day of their arrival, and self-isolate until they get the result of that test back.. story: A BORDERS man has been recognised for his dedication to developing and maintaining walking paths in Earlston, contributing to improving the health of many in his local community.Ian Gibb, who co-founded the Earlston Paths Group was named winner of Community Path Volunteer of the Year at Paths for Allrsquos Volunteer Awards  at a virtual awards ceremony hosted by BBC Radio Scotlandrsquos Fiona Stalker.Since retiring from Royal Mail in , he has been working to develop and then keep the path routes in Earlston in top form ensuring they are accessible for locals and visitors to enjoy.He said: ldquoI have always enjoyed walking and when I retired it was important that I kept myself busy. Thatrsquos why in , I decided to form the group along with my co-founder Jack, who is sadly no longer with us, to develop existing and new walking routes in the area.ldquoThere is plenty of banter when we go out to work on the paths and it gives us a chance to meet new people like contractors, the Paths for All team, local walkers and people visiting the area itrsquos great to build new relationships with these people and hear their story.ldquoThe group is made up of ten volunteers, each contributing in their own way. As well as that, when we have larger projects on the go we are fortunate that more people in the community come out and help.ldquoThe community has really taken ownership of the paths too,anything happens like broken steps, handrails, bridges or even a fallen tree, they know Irsquom the one to call.The charity supports local authorities and communities to develop inclusive environments for people to be active whether walking, cycling or wheeling.Kevin Lafferty, Chief Executive Office at Paths for All, said: ldquoIniduals like Ian highlight the very reason why we host an annual awards ceremony. It is vital that we celebrate and shed light on the outstanding work that volunteers carry out in local communities across Scotland on a daily basis..removeldquoOur volunteerrsquos invaluable contribution is directly working to improve the nationrsquos physical, mental and social health which has been evident throughout the pandemic, with many going above and beyond their normal duties.ldquoHearing the inspirational stories during the award ceremony has highlighted that it is not just enough to say thank you ndash the work undertaken has provided a le line for many and for that wersquore forever grateful.To find out more which Health Walks you can join in the Scottish Borders, visit: www.pathsforall.org.uk healthwalkfinder

story: Nicola Sturgeon gave her weekly Covid update to Parliament this week, just over -hours after hosting a media briefing on the new Omicron iant.So far nine cases of the Omicron iant, which was originally identied in South Africa, have been detected in Scotland.In yesterdays briefing, the first minister urged Scots to up compliance with the current Covid regulations - mask wearing, lateral flow testing, getting vaccinated, keeping rooms ventilated and maintaining high levels of hygiene.She did not introduce any new restrictions during thespeech, but warned that the government would continue to monitor the situation as we learned more about the new iant.Today the first minister stood up in front of MSPs to deliver an update on the current Covid situation in Scotland and said she "hoped" further restrictions would not be required.However, this depends on how the Omicron situation develops, with scientists racing to understand more about the iant over the coming days and weeks.Heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update in Parliament today.... All  cases of Omicron identied in Scotland linked to one eventAll nine of the current identied cases are linked to one single private event, which means that community transmission of the Omicron iant may not be too widespread.None of the people who have tested positive for Omicronin Scotland have so far required hospital tretament.. Looking at COP as source but seems unlikely cases emerged thereThe first minister confirmed Public Health Scotland was looking at COP due to the nature of the event, however said it seems highly unlikely any cases of Omicron emerged there, due to the fact it concluded over -weeks ago..   -year-olds can book second vaccines from today-year-olds in Scotland can book their second vaccines from today, following advice from the JCVI.. Situation in Scotland remains stable.removeDaily case rates continue to hover around ,, with , new cases reported today.A further  deaths were recorded, while  people were in hospital with Covid over past -hours and  in intensive care..
